Article.ArticleTitle: Gridded Emissions of CO, NO <sub>x</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub>, NH<sub>3</sub>, HCl, CH<sub>4</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, BC, and NMVOC from Open Municipal Waste Burning in India.

AbstractText: Accurate emission inventories serve as critical inputs for air quality and climate models but are poorly constrained over India. We present a new municipal open waste burning emission inventory from India (OWBEII), at a resolution of 0.1° × 0.1°. Out of the 216 (201-232) Tg y<sup>-1</sup> of waste produced in the year 2015, 68 (45-105) Tg y<sup>-1</sup> was burned in the open. To determine emissions from waste burning, emission factors of 59 non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs), CH<sub>4</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub>, CO, and NO <sub>x</sub> were measured from garbage fires in rural and urban sites in India. The NMVOC emissions from open waste burning of 1.4-2 Tg y<sup>-1</sup> increase India's total anthropogenic NMVOC budget by 8-12%, while BC emissions (40-110 Ggy<sup>-1</sup>) increase the total anthropogenic BC emissions by 8-12%. Open waste burning in India emits 3-7 Tg y<sup>-1</sup> of CO and 58-130 Tg y<sup>-1</sup> of CO<sub>2</sub>. Emissions increase the total anthropogenic CO and CO<sub>2</sub> in the MIX-Asia inventory by 4-11% and 2-6%, respectively. Open waste burning may affect atmospheric OH reactivity and ozone formation rates downwind of urban centers through the emission of other highly reactive compounds such as acetaldehyde (20-320 Gg y<sup>-1</sup>), propene (50-170 Gg y<sup>-1</sup>), and ethene (50-190 Gg y<sup>-1</sup>) and is s source of carcinogenic benzene (30-280 Gg y<sup>-1</sup>).
